group_1.textRight: We ended up having a very fruitful discussion@at Vaucouleurs.

group_1.textLeft: Yes, and I felt it again:
The resolve of Tart― of La Pucelle―@to bring light to France,
which now endures in her hearts of her comrades.

group_1.textRight: While the Court has its sway on His Majesty's@decisions,
I think you'll be pleased to know that Lord@Richemont and the Duke of Alençon have also@decided to follow in Tart's footsteps.
Apparently, other members of the court are starting@to take their side.
But we still haven't heard anything about@Gilles de Rais...
...nor my father. He must still be in the clutches @of the English.
I hope he comes back safely...

group_1.textLeft: Yeah. All we can do is hope the negotiations for the@prisoner exchange work out.
Even so, we know full well that La Hire...
...will never let himself go down that easily.
Look now, there's another village up ahead.

group_1.textRight: I've heard some of Tart's relatives used to live there.
Would it be alright if we stopped by for a moment?

group_1.textLeft: ...I'm sorry you came all this way.
Unfortunately, it'll be some time before Jeanette's@uncle returns.
As a matter of fact, however, I've actually met@Jeanette in person as well.
Back when she was just a village girl, long before@she was called La Pucelle,
she once stayed at our home with her friend.
The girl's name was...Liz, I think.

group_1.textRight: and assumed that Tart was her granddaughter,
if I understand it all correctly.

group_1.textLeft: Indeed.
We forced her to continue...
...the ruse of being my mother-in-law's@granddaughter.
Yes, with her friend's help.
I thought we'd had her utterly convinced, but...
In truth, I think she must have noticed it about@halfway through.
It was inevitable, if you think about it.
No matter how alike they seemed, they were still@different people.
Now that I remember it all, I'm sorry I asked@Jeanette to do that.
My mother-in-law suspected that something@terrible...
...had happened to her real granddaughter,
but she sensed Jeanette's earnest kindness,@and it saved her.
She told us that just before she passed away.
In the end, instead of dying without knowing the@truth about her granddaughter,
or being told about her death outright...
That approach was the most comforting way for@her to pass on.
She said that sometimes, an illusion can save us,@even though it isn't real.
Ordinary people like me have lived long lives,@and will grow older still,
and yet someone as kind as her had to die@so young...
Ours is a cruel and unjust world.
